contentrichtext.text: {{Greek myth (primordial)}} '''Phanes''' ({{lang-grc|Φάνης}}, from {{lang|grc|φαίνω}}, ''phainō'', "I bring to light"), or '''Protogonos''' ({{lang-el|Πρωτογόνος}}, "First-born"), was the mystic primeval [[deity]] of procreation and the generation of new life, who was introduced into [[Greek mythology]] by the [[Orphics|Orphic tradition]]; other names for this [[Classical Greece|Classical Greek]] Orphic concept included [[Ericapaeus]] ({{lang|grc|Ἠρικαπαῖος or Ἠρικεπαῖος}} "power"{{fact|date=July 2009}}) and [[Metis (mythology)|Metis]] ("thought"). In these myths Phanes is often equated with [[Eros (god)|Eros]] and [[Mithras]] and has been depicted as a deity emerging from a [[cosmic egg]], entwined with a [[serpent (symbolism)|serpent]]. He had a helmet and had broad, golden wings. Many threads of earlier myths are apparent in the new tradition. Phanes was believed to have been hatched from the [[World-Egg]] of [[Chronos]] (Time) and [[Ananke (mythology)|Ananke]] (Necessity). His older wife [[Nyx (mythology)|Nyx]] (Night) called him Protogenus. As she created nighttime, he created daytime. He also created the method of creation by mingling. He was made the ruler of the deities and passed the [[sceptre]] to Nyx. This new Orphic tradition states that Nyx later gave the sceptre to her son [[Uranus (mythology)|Uranos]] before it passed to [[Cronus]] and then to Zeus, who retained it. It is also believed that by his centuries-old battle with Chaos, the creation of birds took place as the result. The "Protogonos Theogony" is known through the commentary in the [[Derveni papyrus]] and references in [[Empedocles]] and [[Pindar]]. ==External links== *[http://timelessmyths.com/classical/primeval.html#Protogonus Protogonus (Phanes)] *[http://theoi.com/Protogenos/Phanes.html Theoi Project: Phanes] *[http://www.stoa.org/sol-entries/phi/72 Suda entry] *[http://www.coinlink.com/News/ancients/first-money-in-human-history-worth-200000-euros/ Phanes coins] [[Category:Greek gods]] [[Category:Fertility gods]] [[Category:Creator deities]] [[Category:Greek mythology]] [[Category:Ancient Greek religion]] {{Greek-deity-stub}}
